<h2 class="wp-block-heading"><span class="ez-toc-section" id="24_Noblebright"></span>24. Noblebright<span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span></h2>



<p><strong>Noblebright = Noble/heroic characters in bright worlds</strong>. <strong>A single hero can significantly alter world events.</strong></p>



<p>On the opposite side of the spectrum from Grimdark, we have Noblebright. These worlds inspire awe and are filled with breathtaking landscapes and magical creatures. Although there is darkness and evil, virtuous heroes prevail. Love, hope, and redemption win out through noble sacrifices.</p>



<p><strong>Examples of Noblebright Fantasy</strong></p>



<p>This term was <a href="https://cjbrightley.com/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">coined by author C.J. Brightly</a>, so if youre interested in this subgenre, exploring her books is probably a good place to start. (I haven&#8217;t read her yet myself.)</p>



<p>Much classic fantasy is considered noblebright, including <em>The Chronicles of Narnia, The Chronicles of Prydain, </em>and<em> The Lord of the Rings.</em></p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-large is-resized"><picture><source srcset="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Fellowship-of-the-Ring-on-a-quest-1024x683.webp 1024w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Fellowship-of-the-Ring-on-a-quest-300x200.webp 300w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Fellowship-of-the-Ring-on-a-quest-768x512.webp 768w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Fellowship-of-the-Ring-on-a-quest.webp 1200w" sizes="auto, (max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" type="image/webp"><img src="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Fellowship-of-the-Ring-on-a-quest-1024x683.jpg" height="683" width="1024" srcset="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Fellowship-of-the-Ring-on-a-quest-1024x683.jpg 1024w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Fellowship-of-the-Ring-on-a-quest-300x200.jpg 300w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Fellowship-of-the-Ring-on-a-quest-768x512.jpg 768w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Fellowship-of-the-Ring-on-a-quest.jpg 1200w" sizes="auto, (max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" class="wp-image-1285 sp-no-webp" alt="The distant figures of the Fellowship of the Ring make their way through enormous boulders shot-through with waterfalls." loading="lazy" decoding="async" style="width:800px"  > </picture><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">Tolkien&#8217;s work is classified as Noblebright</figcaption></figure>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading"><span class="ez-toc-section" id="25_Grimbright"></span>25. Grimbright<span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span></h2>



<p><strong>Grimbright = Grim characters in a bright world.</strong> <strong>Characters fight for a better tomorrow, but cant effect huge change.</strong></p>



<p>To give people ways of describing stories that fall somewhere on the spectrum between Grimdark and Noblebright, we get two additional subgenres: grimbright and nobledark.</p>



<p>If your brain is spinning right now, I feel you! <a href="https://cosmicdraft.com/what-is-grimbright-a-unique-vision-of-a-dystopian-world/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">This article proved helpful</a> in differentiating these subgenres.</p>



<p>In Grimbright, though the worlds are still dark, bleak, and broken, theres still a moral grounding, a fight for good. Sacrifices mean something, justice exists, and the characters fight for change, but theres a limit to what they can accomplish.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading"><span class="ez-toc-section" id="26_Nobledark"></span>26. Nobledark<span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span></h2>



<p><strong>Noblebright = Noble/Heroic characters in a dark world.</strong> <strong>A single hero can significantly alter world events.</strong></p>



<p>So, whats nobledark? Author Jon Cronshaw says Nobledark stories are ones where the hero, despite being dragged through the mud, still believes in a better tomorrow.</p>



<p>I reckon <em>The Witcher</em> fits under this category because he tries to follow a moral compass, he has values, and his efforts on Ciris behalf make a difference. Granted, I didnt read all the books, so Im basing this on the ones I&#8217;ve read.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading"><span class="ez-toc-section" id="27_Hopepunk"></span>27. Hopepunk<span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span></h2>



<p>Hopepunk is an emerging subgenre, and only time will tell if the term will stick around or if it&#8217;s too ambiguous to last, especially since it, too, has been called the opposite of grimdark. Confusing much?</p>



<p>This term was coined by author Alexandra Rowland, but definitions vary, so let me tell you what <em>I</em> think hopepunk is, and why I like it.</p>



<p>I think its clear to all of us how messed up and broken the world is. But thats not all there is. There is beauty, and things worth fighting for. So even though we can look at the world and despair, hopepunk invites us to have a different response.</p>



<p><strong>What if we decided that the very act of fighting for change is worthwhile? What if we looked the problem in the eye, linked arms, and tried to solve whatever small part of it we can?</strong> What if we summoned our guts and rage, refused to retreat, became resilient, and believed that even though the world isnt perfect, it can be better?</p>



<p>That to me is hopepunk.</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-large is-resized"><picture><source srcset="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Angel-and-Feather-1024x683.webp 1024w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Angel-and-Feather-300x200.webp 300w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Angel-and-Feather-768x512.webp 768w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Angel-and-Feather.webp 1200w" sizes="auto, (max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" type="image/webp"><img src="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Angel-and-Feather-1024x683.jpg" height="683" width="1024" srcset="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Angel-and-Feather-1024x683.jpg 1024w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Angel-and-Feather-300x200.jpg 300w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Angel-and-Feather-768x512.jpg 768w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Angel-and-Feather.jpg 1200w" sizes="auto, (max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" class="wp-image-1292 sp-no-webp" alt="A carved wooden angel on a black background, with a feather cutting diagonally across the foreground. It is meant to portray Hopepunks rejection of cynicism." loading="lazy" decoding="async" style="width:800px"  > </picture></figure>



<p>Its less idealistic and black-and-white than noblebright, it rejects the despair and cynicism of grimdark, and instead, rebelliously embraces hope. But maybe its just an edgier version of noblebright? <a href="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/group/">Join my Facebook group and tell me what you think</a>!</p>



<p><strong>Examples of Hopepunk Fantasy</strong></p>



<p>As I mentioned in my intro, I found one of my favorite books thanks to the term hopepunk, so itll always hold a soft spot in my heart. <a href="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/the-goblin-emperor-review/" data-type="post" data-id="798">That book is <em>The Goblin Emperor</em></a> by Katherine Addison.</p>



<p>Rowland, who coined the term, cites the character of Sam Vines in Terry Pratchetts <em>Guards! Guards! </em>As the quintessential example of <a href="https://www.denofgeek.com/culture/a-hopepunk-guide-interview-with-alexandra-rowland/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Hopepunk in an interview with Den of Geek</a>:</p>



<p>Hes tired, hes flawed, hes jaded and cynical And yet he still, right at the basement foundations of his heart, believes in something. He gets out of the ditch, sobers up, gets his life in order. He holds onto his principles with a white-knuckled grip because he knows how easily they could slip away from him. He knows how easy and comfortable it would be to let himself become corrupted by his cynicism. But he stands up, sometimes against whole armies, and refuses to budge from what he knows is right and just. He is the very embodiment of: No, you move. And they do. The whole world does.&nbsp;</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading"><span class="ez-toc-section" id="How_Subgenres_Helped_Me_Find_A_New_Favorite_Book"></span>How Subgenres Helped Me Find A New Favorite Book<span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span></h2>



<p>Last year, I found one of my new favorite books thanks to a subgenre list.</p>



<p>I was reading through and noticed a subgenre Id never heard of before. Hopepunk? What is<em> that</em>? Intrigued, I found a list of books categorized <a href="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/the-goblin-emperor-review/" data-type="post" data-id="798">as hopepunk and checked out <em>The Goblin Emperor</em></a> by Katherine Addison from my library app.</p>



<p>I read it once. Then, I immediately read it a second time (rare in itself). Next, I listened to the audiobook. I loved it. I added the paperback version to my Christmas wishlist, and my parents got it for me. So, of course, I read it again. And listened to the audiobook again, cause why not? From January to March, I re-read my favorite sections before bed each night.</p>



<p>In short, I was <em>obsessed</em>. It was fantastic. That book has been a comfort and a joy to me ever since I discovered it. I cant even tell you how many times Ive read it now. And although Im not currently re-reading it obsessively, its on my shelf whenever I need it.</p>



<p>That, my friends, is the power of subgenres. And subgenre lists. And if you want to go even further, you can search for tropes as well.</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-large is-resized"><picture><source srcset="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/image-1024x683.webp 1024w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/image-300x200.webp 300w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/image-768x512.webp 768w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/image-1536x1024.webp 1536w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/image.webp 1638w" sizes="auto, (max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" type="image/webp"><img src="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/image-1024x683.png" height="683" width="1024" srcset="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/image-1024x683.png 1024w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/image-300x200.png 300w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/image-768x512.png 768w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/image-1536x1024.png 1536w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/image.png 1638w" sizes="auto, (max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" class="wp-image-1288 sp-no-webp" alt="Yvonne with one of her favorite books, &quot;The Goblin Emperor&quot; by Katherine Addison. It is considered hopepunk fantasy by some." loading="lazy" decoding="async" style="width:800px"  > </picture><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">Me, with my obsessive re-read</figcaption></figure>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading"><span class="ez-toc-section" id="Subgenres_vs_Tropes"></span>Subgenres vs Tropes<span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span></h2>



<p>If we think of subgenres as sub-categories of fantasy with particular flavor profiles, (like Italian, Caribbean, or Chinese are sub-categories in the realm of cuisine), <strong>we can think of tropes as the common <em>ingredients</em> that we find across a wide range of novels</strong>.</p>



<p>For example, the protagonists in many fantasy and young adult books are orphans. Because this story element is common across lots of books in the genre, it is considered a trope. And if it&#8217;s a trope you like, you can search for books with that particular story element (such as the <a href="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/dead-parents-trope/" data-type="post" data-id="1336">dead parents trope common in young adult fantasy</a>). Or, if you are up-to-your-ears in orphan books, you might prefer a book that <em>doesn&#8217;t </em>include that ingredient.</p>



<p>Not all readers like to look for books this way, but others do.</p>



<p>Using tropes to search for books is no different than Googling a soup recipe that will use up the bean sprouts in danger of going bad in your fridge. Or requesting a focaccia recipe that includes rosemary and Dijon mustard because that sounds good to you right now. Or saying, I want a pizza, but make it a bacon pesto sprinkled with smoked chile flakes.</p>



<p>Im a big fan of the found family trope, so when Im perusing book lists or asking for recommendations, I might say something like, I would love to read a nautical adventure fantasy with found family and a forced proximity romance subplot. And somebody might be able to recommend one to me.</p>



<p>Cool, right?</p>



<p>Check out my post <a href="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/fantasy-tropes/" data-type="post" data-id="1349">on fantasy book tropes to learn to find books with ingredients</a> you like.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading"><span class="ez-toc-section" id="FAQs"></span>FAQs<span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span></h2>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading"><span class="ez-toc-section" id="What_genre_is_fantasy_in_the_real_world"></span>What genre is fantasy in the real world?<span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span></h3>



<p>Fantasy novels set in the real world are low fantasy. These stories take place in the real world, where magic is and other fantastical elements exist, but are often hidden. Additional subgenres in the real world include historical, gaslamp, steampunk, urban, and paranormal.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading"><span class="ez-toc-section" id="Made_It_This_Far_Heres_a_Quick_Win"></span>Made It This Far? Heres a Quick Win<span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span></h2>



<p>The subgenres of fantasy can be hard to define with exactness, especially as new ones emerge, fuse, and spark variations. But dont stress about it. <strong>In the end, they&#8217;re nothing more than search terms to help us describe our reading preferences so we can find the books we like, recommend books to others, and discover new flavors of fantasy we</strong>d like to try.</p>



<p>Being able to say, This book is a political steampunk-inspired high fantasy with personal stakes, only matters if saying that inspires you to read it (or prevents you from reading it because you know youd hate it).</p>



<p><strong>An intro to some of my favorite subgenres</strong>:</p>



<p>This list of five young adult fantasy series includes political fantasy, academy fantasy, mythic fantasy, epic dystopian high fantasy, and a western-inspired high fantasy adventure series:</p>



<div class="wp-block-columns has-theme-palette-3-background-color has-background is-layout-flex wp-container-core-columns-is-layout-9d6595d7 wp-block-columns-is-layout-flex">

</article><!-- #post-1245 -->

<div class="entry-author entry-author-style-center">
	<div class="entry-author-profile author-profile vcard">
		<div class="entry-author-avatar">
					</div>
		<b class="entry-author-name author-name fn"><a href="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/author/inkfilaments/" title="Posts by Yvonne McArthur" rel="author">Yvonne McArthur</a></b>
				<div class="entry-author-description author-bio">
			<p>Yvonne McArthur is a freelance writer and developmental editor based in Guatemala. Growing up between cultures sparked her love for telling stories that encourage us to be kinder, more courageous, more connected humans. Shes completed one full-length fantasy novel and recently started her second. Her short fiction has appeared in anthologies and online, and her editorial work helps writers sharpen their voice, strengthen their story arcs, and connect more deeply with their readers. When shes not working on manuscripts, youll find her riding her motorcycle with her canine sidekick, hiking volcanoes, or devouring her latest read.</p>
		</div>
		<div class="entry-author-follow author-follow">
								<a href="https://www.facebook.com/YvonneMcArthurAuthor/" class="facebook-link social-button" target="_blank" rel="noopener" title="Follow Yvonne McArthur on Facebook">
						<span class="kadence-svg-iconset"><svg class="kadence-svg-icon kadence-facebook-svg" fill="currentColor" version="1.1" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="32" height="32" viewBox="0 0 32 32"><title>Facebook</title><path d="M31.997 15.999c0-8.836-7.163-15.999-15.999-15.999s-15.999 7.163-15.999 15.999c0 7.985 5.851 14.604 13.499 15.804v-11.18h-4.062v-4.625h4.062v-3.525c0-4.010 2.389-6.225 6.043-6.225 1.75 0 3.581 0.313 3.581 0.313v3.937h-2.017c-1.987 0-2.607 1.233-2.607 2.498v3.001h4.437l-0.709 4.625h-3.728v11.18c7.649-1.2 13.499-7.819 13.499-15.804z"></path>
				</svg></span>					</a>

My stories feature spunky characters who take on everything from overly practical parents to teleporting assassinsall while becoming kinder, more courageous, and more connected humans.</p><div class="kt-blocks-info-box-learnmore-wrap"><span class="kt-blocks-info-box-learnmore">Click here to learn more about me</span></div></div></a></div>

						<div class="content-wrap">
				<article id="post-1245" class="entry content-bg single-entry post-1245 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-category-fantasy tag-featured">
	<div class="entry-content-wrap">
		<header class="entry-header post-title title-align-center title-tablet-align-inherit title-mobile-align-inherit">
	<h1 class="entry-title">27 Subgenres of Fantasy: Find the Perfect Books for You</h1><div class="entry-meta entry-meta-divider-dot">
	<span class="posted-by"><span class="meta-label">By</span><span class="author vcard"><a class="url fn n" href="https://yvonnemcarthur.com">Yvonne McArthur</a></span></span>					<span class="posted-on">
						<time class="entry-date published" datetime="2025-06-09T16:11:34-06:00" itemprop="datePublished">June 9, 2025</time><time class="updated" datetime="2025-07-01T09:48:12-06:00" itemprop="dateModified">July 1, 2025</time>					</span>
										<span class="updated-on">
						<span class="meta-label">Updated on</span><time class="entry-date published updated" datetime="2025-07-01T09:48:12-06:00" itemprop="dateModified">July 1, 2025</time>					</span>
					</div><!-- .entry-meta -->
</header><!-- .entry-header -->
	<div class="post-thumbnail article-post-thumbnail kadence-thumbnail-position-below kadence-thumbnail-ratio-2-3">
		<div class="post-thumbnail-inner">
			<picture><source srcset="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/YA-Fantasy-Enthusiasts-Banner.webp 1640w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/YA-Fantasy-Enthusiasts-Banner-300x157.webp 300w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/YA-Fantasy-Enthusiasts-Banner-1024x536.webp 1024w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/YA-Fantasy-Enthusiasts-Banner-768x402.webp 768w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/YA-Fantasy-Enthusiasts-Banner-1536x804.webp 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1640px) 100vw, 1640px" type="image/webp"><img src="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/YA-Fantasy-Enthusiasts-Banner.jpg" height="858" width="1640" srcset="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/YA-Fantasy-Enthusiasts-Banner.jpg 1640w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/YA-Fantasy-Enthusiasts-Banner-300x157.jpg 300w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/YA-Fantasy-Enthusiasts-Banner-1024x536.jpg 1024w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/YA-Fantasy-Enthusiasts-Banner-768x402.jpg 768w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/YA-Fantasy-Enthusiasts-Banner-1536x804.jpg 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1640px) 100vw, 1640px" class="post-top-featured wp-post-image sp-no-webp" alt="An array of fantasy novels are set up on pale wooden crates in front of a pale green wall, arfully arranged among clay candles, an olive wood bowl, a maple box, and miniscule walnut candles" decoding="async" fetchpriority="high"  > </picture>		</div>
	</div><!-- .post-thumbnail -->
			
<div class="entry-content single-content">
	
<p>All lovers of the fantasy genre know that it&#8217;s a venture into the realm of the fantastic and offers a range of books as vast as the imagination. It encompasses everything from stories about teens on a magical quest in present-day Virginia to Parshendi bonding spren on one of the planets of the Cosmere. As a fantasy writer and obsessive reader of the genre, I think thats awesome. <strong>But the genre&#8217;s huge scope also presents a problem: It is <em>so </em>varied that it becomes complicated to find books that match our tastes.</strong></p>



<p>That&#8217;s where the subgenres of fantasy come to the rescue.</p>



<p>Imagine asking a friend about their eating preferences so you can invite them over for dinner and having them say something like, Food is great or I like everything. </p>



<p>The first answer is too general to be helpful, and the second isnt honest because, in truth, they abhor eggplant, have an allergy to nutmeg, and wont touch liver with a four-foot fork. It would be so much easier to meal plan if they could tell you, &#8220;I adore Tex-Mex&#8221; or &#8220;I&#8217;m a sucker for Ethiopian cuisine.&#8221;</p>



<p><strong>Just as &#8220;Tex-Mex&#8221; and &#8220;Ethiopian&#8221; are sub-categories of food that give you a clear indication what kind of ingredients and spice profiles you&#8217;re in for, subgenres help us describe distinct flavors <em>or sub-categories</em> of fantasy.</strong></p>



<p>What do I mean by flavors? Well, if you like stories set in grim dystopian worlds full of monsters and spine-tingling chills, you might like dark fantasy. Whereas if you&#8217;re craving a nutty, off-the-wall tale that makes you laugh out loud, you&#8217;ll want to try comic fantasy.</p>



<p><strong>Think of subgenres as powerful search tools that help you find books to suit your tastes.</strong> For example, I love adventure and political fantasy, but don&#8217;t care for grimdark or romantasy. And last year, I found one of my new favorite books thanks to a subgenre list.</p>



<p>The whole point of subgenres is to help you find books you like. Im certain you have preferences, too, even if you dont know what they are yet or aren&#8217;t sure how to describe them.</p>



<p><strong>By the end of this article, youll be able to say which subgenres you like, which youre curious to sample, and which land on your Do Not Ingest: Risk of Vomiting list, with curated book recommendations for each.</strong> </p>



<p>If a subgenre sounds fun, jot it down, buy or borrow some of the books I recommend, and/or ask fantasy book clubs and communities for recommendations in the subgenres that pique your interest.</p>



<p><strong>Disclaimer:</strong> Think of subgenres as tags rather than boxes. Defining them is subjective. To borrow a line from <em>Pirates of the Caribbean</em>, these classifications are more what you&#8217;d call &#8216;guidelines&#8217; than actual rules.&#8221; And just as a recipe can fall under &#8220;vegan&#8221; <em>and</em> &#8220;Thai&#8221; <em>and</em> &#8220;dessert&#8221;, fantasy books can be tagged under multiple subgenres.</p>



<div id="ez-toc-container" class="ez-toc-v2_0_80 counter-hierarchy ez-toc-counter ez-toc-grey ez-toc-container-direction">
<div class="ez-toc-title-container">
<p class="ez-toc-title" style="cursor:inherit">Table of Contents</p>
<span class="ez-toc-title-toggle"><a href="#" class="ez-toc-pull-right ez-toc-btn ez-toc-btn-xs ez-toc-btn-default ez-toc-toggle" aria-label="Toggle Table of Content"><span class="ez-toc-js-icon-con"><span class=""><span class="eztoc-hide" style="display:none;">Toggle</span><span class="ez-toc-icon-toggle-span"><svg style="fill: #999;color:#999" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" class="list-377408" width="20px" height="20px" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none"><path d="M6 6H4v2h2V6zm14 0H8v2h12V6zM4 11h2v2H4v-2zm16 0H8v2h12v-2zM4 16h2v2H4v-2zm16 0H8v2h12v-2z" fill="currentColor"></path></svg><svg style="fill: #999;color:#999" class="arrow-unsorted-368013" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="10px" height="10px" viewBox="0 0 24 24" version="1.2" baseProfile="tiny"><path d="M18.2 9.3l-6.2-6.3-6.2 6.3c-.2.2-.3.4-.3.7s.1.5.3.7c.2.2.4.3.7.3h11c.3 0 .5-.1.7-.3.2-.2.3-.5.3-.7s-.1-.5-.3-.7zM5.8 14.7l6.2 6.3 6.2-6.3c.2-.2.3-.5.3-.7s-.1-.5-.3-.7c-.2-.2-.4-.3-.7-.3h-11c-.3 0-.5.1-.7.3-.2.2-.3.5-.3.7s.1.5.3.7z"/></svg></span></span></span></a></span></div>

Heres a Quick Win</a></li></ul></nav></div>
<h2 class="wp-block-heading"><span class="ez-toc-section" id="1_High_Fantasy"></span>1. High Fantasy<span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span></h2>



<p>Books that are high fantasy take place in completely different worlds from our own. Tolkien called these secondary worlds. </p>



<p><strong>They often include magic, mythical creatures, characters from different races, invented cultures, and landscapes that range from the familiar to the fabulously refreshing.</strong></p>



<p>This subgenre invites us&nbsp;into the weird, wild, and brilliant, into terrifying darkness and breathtaking beauty. It is the best kind of escape, the most <em>arresting</em> by its strangeness. In it, we not only leave behind our present troubles and concerns, but we leave behind the world as we know it.</p>



<p>High fantasy is, as Tolkien says in his essay &#8220;On Faerie Stories&#8221;, one of the hardest to write well because the farther we get from the rules and characteristics of our primary world, the more challenging it is to maintain an &#8220;inner consistency of reality&#8221;. </p>



<p>Ah, but when done well, these secondary worlds offer an allure like no other. They promise something captivating: a voyage into places crafted from pure imagination, founded upon a stringent inner logic, and developed by delicious innovation.</p>



<p>I&#8217;m a fan. Can you tell?</p>



<p><strong>Examples of High Fantasy</strong></p>



<p><em>The Lord of the Rings</em> is classic high fantasy. Tolkiens Middle-earth is a world unto itself with a detailed and complex history, and over fourteen languages invented by Tolkien himself. There&#8217;s a good reason he&#8217;s called &#8216;the father of fantasy.&#8217; Or, to riff on Brandon Sanderson, &#8220;Grandpa Tolkien.&#8221; </p>



<p>My parents read <em>The Lord of the Rings</em> to me and my siblings when we were kids, with my dad voice-acting the characters. That&#8217;s probably where my love for the genre began.</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-large is-resized"><picture><source srcset="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Gandalf-in-the-ferns-1024x683.webp 1024w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Gandalf-in-the-ferns-300x200.webp 300w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Gandalf-in-the-ferns-768x512.webp 768w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Gandalf-in-the-ferns.webp 1200w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" type="image/webp"><img src="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Gandalf-in-the-ferns-1024x683.jpg" height="683" width="1024" srcset="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Gandalf-in-the-ferns-1024x683.jpg 1024w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Gandalf-in-the-ferns-300x200.jpg 300w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Gandalf-in-the-ferns-768x512.jpg 768w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Gandalf-in-the-ferns.jpg 1200w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" class="wp-image-1256 sp-no-webp" alt="The wizard, Gandalf, in his flowing gray robes and pointed hat, striding through a blustery green meadow in the rain. The Lord of the Rings by J.R.R. Tolkien is the signature example of the high fantasy subgenre." decoding="async" style="width:800px"  > </picture><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">Gandalf the Gray from <em>The Lord of the Rings</em>a classic example of high fantasy.</figcaption></figure>



<p>Other high fantasy books I love include pretty much all of Brandon Sandersons books (I once read 25 of his books in one year.) The worlds he comes up with are unique, from the strange mists of Scadriel in <em>The Mistborn Saga</em> to the fascinating crustacean-inspired world of Roshar in <em>The Stormlight Archives</em>. That series is my favorite of his so far, starting with <em>The Way of Kings</em>. </p>



<p>They are perfect for readers who like big casts of characters and complex plots, and who don&#8217;t mind hefty books with hundreds of pages. Most of the audio versions are 50-60 hourscue me listening at 1.75 speed so I could finish before my library loan was due. But, Sanderson also has a short story collection called <em>Arcanum Unbounded</em> with one of my all-time-favorite short fantasy stories: <em>The Emperor&#8217;s Soul.</em> Start there for an intro.</p>



<p><a href="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/review-beyond-mercedes-lackey/"><em>Beyond</em> by Mercedes Lackey </a>is another great high fantasy book.</p>



<p>In YA, I&#8217;ve enjoyed the African-inspired world of Aritsar in <em>Raybearer</em> by Jordan Ifueko.</p>



<p>In middle grade, I found <em>The Trials of Morrighan Crow</em> entertaining. The story takes place in Nevermoor, a city in the First Pocket of the Free State.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading"><span class="ez-toc-section" id="2_Low_Fantasy"></span>2. Low Fantasy<span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span></h2>



<p>Standing in counterpoint to high fantasy, low fantasy is set in worlds much like our own. Low fantasy feels more grounded in reality, more familiar. Its recognizable, but with a flair, a twist, something unexpected. It is our grandmas shortbread with a swirl of lime zest and a burst of lavender flowers.</p>



<p><strong>In low fantasy, the world behaves like ours in some respects, but in others is shot through with the mystical, the supernatural, the magical.</strong> Often, the magic in these books is hidden or only accessible to a few people. Here we find secret societies, sentient libraries, and realms that are invisible to all but those who have eyes to <em>see</em>.</p>



<p>Part of the appeal and delight of low fantasy is that the stories are about people much like us, with jobs and TVs and homework but who encounter something fantastical: dangerous, scary, wild, enchanting, and <em>almost </em>plausible. It makes us feel like something magical could happen to us, too. Just now, as were going about our mundane lives. It could happen at any time, when we least expect it. And that is a delightful thought, is it not?</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-large is-resized"><picture><source srcset="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/The-Raven-Boys-1024x683.webp 1024w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/The-Raven-Boys-300x200.webp 300w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/The-Raven-Boys-768x512.webp 768w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/The-Raven-Boys.webp 1200w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" type="image/webp"><img src="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/The-Raven-Boys-1024x683.jpg" height="683" width="1024" srcset="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/The-Raven-Boys-1024x683.jpg 1024w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/The-Raven-Boys-300x200.jpg 300w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/The-Raven-Boys-768x512.jpg 768w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/The-Raven-Boys.jpg 1200w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" class="wp-image-1257 sp-no-webp" alt="A phone sits between curved slats of wood between a glittering mica-encrusted stone and a gray and black feather. On the screen is the cover image of &quot;The Raven Boys&quot; by Maggie Stiefvater. It shows a crow, legs extended toward four grayed-out teen boys wearing matching jackets. The Raven Boys is a great example of Low Fantasy" decoding="async" style="width:800px"  > </picture><figcaption class="wp-element-caption"><em>The Raven Boys</em> is a great example of Low Fantasy</figcaption></figure>



<p>Low Fantasy books often fit into other subgenres. Some common ones include modern, historical, urban, paranormal, and portal fantasy novels (which usually begin in the real world). More on those shortly.</p>



<p><strong>Examples of Low Fantasy</strong></p>



<p>The <em>Harry Potter</em> series contains aspects of low fantasy because every summer, Harry is forbidden from doing magic and is stuck in the non-magical, everyday world of regular Britain with his relatives.</p>



<p><em>The Raven Cycle</em> series by Maggie Stiefvater is set in the fictional modern-day town of Henrietta, Virginia. Much of the world feels familiar but with the addition of ley lines, mythical Welsh kings, and dream magic.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading"><span class="ez-toc-section" id="3_Urban_Fantasy"></span>3. Urban Fantasy<span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span></h2>



<p>Although it seems <em>pretty</em> darn obvious that urban fantasy books take place inyou guessed itcities, not ALL fantasy books set in cities are urban. Yeah, its weird, I know. <strong>To be an urban fantasy, the book has to be set in a modern or modern-adjacent, real-world city, one where magic is hidden to all but a few.</strong>&nbsp;</p>



<p>The key thing to remember is that urban fantasy is a subset of low fantasy. So even though <em>The Lies of Locke Lamora</em> takes place entirely in the city of Camorr, that city is not part of our world. Camorr is in a secondary (high fantasy) world. Thus the book is not urban fantasy.</p>



<p>Urban fantasy has a particular mystique. It&#8217;s dark with an edge of complexity that catches in the throat like molasses. </p>



<p>Here we enter vampire lairs, solve mysteries, get lost in labyrinths, and cross into alternate versions of the neighborhoods we think we know. There could be escaped tigers in the sewers, speakeasies behind graffiti, adventures, mysteries, romancetoss it back like a strong drink and hit the streets.</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-large is-resized"><picture><source srcset="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Neverwhere-and-Cityscape-1024x683.webp 1024w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Neverwhere-and-Cityscape-300x200.webp 300w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Neverwhere-and-Cityscape-768x512.webp 768w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Neverwhere-and-Cityscape.webp 1200w" sizes="auto, (max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" type="image/webp"><img src="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Neverwhere-and-Cityscape-1024x683.jpg" height="683" width="1024" srcset="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Neverwhere-and-Cityscape-1024x683.jpg 1024w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Neverwhere-and-Cityscape-300x200.jpg 300w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Neverwhere-and-Cityscape-768x512.jpg 768w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Neverwhere-and-Cityscape.jpg 1200w" sizes="auto, (max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" class="wp-image-1259 sp-no-webp" alt="A book showing a picture of London and a train track disappearing underground sits in front of a dramatic painting of yellow and purple planet with a city of skyscrapers rising in front of it. Neverwhere is a great example of Urban Fantasy." loading="lazy" decoding="async" style="width:800px"  > </picture><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">Neil Gaiman&#8217;s Urban Fantasy, <em>Neverwhere</em>, is set in two versions of London: London Above and London Below.</figcaption></figure>



<p><strong>Examples of Urban Fantasy</strong></p>



<p>Neil Gaimans <em>Neverwhere </em>is about a man from regular, real-world London who falls into the fantastical world of London Below. There, a girl named Anesthesia acts as his guide, assassins trail in his wake, an angel sends him on a quest, and a young woman named Door opens doors to the unexpected.</p>



<p>Cassandra Clares <em>The Mortal Instruments</em> series is set in modern-day New York City, where a secret society of human-angel hybrids protects the city from demons and rogue werewolves, vampires, and warlocks. Teenager Clary Fray was living an ordinary life in Brooklyn and had no idea this whole other world existed. Until one night, she witnesses a murder no one else can see</p>



<p>Fun, right?</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading"><span class="ez-toc-section" id="4_Epic_Fantasy"></span>4. Epic Fantasy<span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span></h2>



<p>While the subgenres weve focused on so far are primarily defined by their setting, epic fantasy describes the storys <em>scope</em>. <strong>Epics are <em>epic.</em> They are high-stakes adventures about characters who face overwhelming antagonistic forces</strong>: The Dark Lord Sauron with his far-seeing eye and hordes of orcs, immortal emperors who are impossible to kill, gods, armies, kingdoms</p>



<p>History is made on the pages of these stories. Lone warriors take up arms, join forces, and stand like with swords raised against forces that strike at their ideals, endanger their loved ones, and threaten the fabric of their worlds.</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-large is-resized"><picture><source srcset="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Raybearer-Stilllife-1024x683.webp 1024w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Raybearer-Stilllife-300x200.webp 300w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Raybearer-Stilllife-768x512.webp 768w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Raybearer-Stilllife.webp 1200w" sizes="auto, (max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" type="image/webp"><img src="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Raybearer-Stilllife-1024x683.jpg" height="683" width="1024" srcset="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Raybearer-Stilllife-1024x683.jpg 1024w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Raybearer-Stilllife-300x200.jpg 300w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Raybearer-Stilllife-768x512.jpg 768w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Raybearer-Stilllife.jpg 1200w" sizes="auto, (max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" class="wp-image-1261 sp-no-webp" alt="A carved blackwood elephant candlestick, a phone, and a tea candle inside a wooden holder are arranged in front of a blue, green, and gold scarf from Tanzania. The phone screen shows the cover image of &quot;Raybearer&quot; by Jordan Ifuekoan epic Afro-fantasy novel." loading="lazy" decoding="async" style="width:800px"  > </picture><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">Jordan Ifueko&#8217;s epic fantasy, <em>Raybearer</em>, covers sweeping world-changing events</figcaption></figure>



<p>Usually, epic fantasies are also high fantasies, but not all high fantasies are epics. For example, <em>The Goblin Emperor</em> is a very personal story about one half-goblins unexpected rise to power and his personal and political struggles. Its very much a high fantasy, but not an epic.</p>



<p><strong>Examples of Epic Fantasy</strong></p>



<p>By contrast, in <em>The Lord of the Rings</em> Frodo and Sam toil toward Mount Doom while Aragorn, Gandalf, and the men of Gondor draw Saurons eye (and his forces) in a last-ditch effort to give Frodo the chance he needs destroy the one ring and save the world from Dark Lords domination. Epic.</p>



<p>Sandersons <em>Mistborn Saga </em>and <em>Stormlight Archives</em> books also fall solidly under the epic fantasy subgenre, with the fate of the world (and the Cosmere itself) falling into the hands of the cast of characters.</p>



<p>Likewise, in <em>Raybearer</em>, Tarisai is wrapped up in the politics of Aritsar, the fate of the empire, and of the world itself.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading"><span class="ez-toc-section" id="5_Adventure_Fantasy"></span>5. Adventure Fantasy<span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span></h2>



<p><strong>Daring quests, intrepid explorers, action-packed escapades, and fantastic feats.</strong> Welcome to adventure fantasy, flavored with boldness, salted with heroics, and shot through with danger. I love this subgenre, probably because I love stories about journeys and wild lands and mythic beasts.</p>



<p>Adventure fantasies let us ride on the backs of massive birds, wyverns, and dragons, cross rapids, fight battles, sneak through castle windows, climb snow-drowned peaks, find our courage (possibly after running away screaming), and encounter luminous wonders we won&#8217;t forget.</p>



<p>The stakes grab us by the throat. The villains steal our breath. We encounter death time and again, and are slapped in the face by horrors. But we don&#8217;t give up. We keep walking, keep fighting, keep hoping, until eventually, we prevail.</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-large is-resized"><picture><source srcset="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Smaug-Illustration-1024x683.webp 1024w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Smaug-Illustration-300x200.webp 300w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Smaug-Illustration-768x512.webp 768w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Smaug-Illustration.webp 1200w" sizes="auto, (max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" type="image/webp"><img src="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Smaug-Illustration-1024x683.jpg" height="683" width="1024" srcset="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Smaug-Illustration-1024x683.jpg 1024w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Smaug-Illustration-300x200.jpg 300w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Smaug-Illustration-768x512.jpg 768w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Smaug-Illustration.jpg 1200w" sizes="auto, (max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" class="wp-image-1263 sp-no-webp" alt="A pen drawing of Smaug, the dragon from J.R.R. Tolkien&#039;s &quot;The Hobbit&quot;, crouches over his hoard of treasure with a fierce expression. This is a great example of the adventure fantasy subgenre." loading="lazy" decoding="async" style="width:800px"  > </picture><figcaption class="wp-element-caption"><em>The Hobbit</em> is classic adventure fantasy</figcaption></figure>



<p><strong>Examples of Adventure Fantasy</strong></p>



<p>Adventure fantasies can be fun, high-flying, comedic tales like <em>Alcatraz vs the Evil Librarians </em>or <em>Howls Moving Castle</em> or they could involve kidnappings, dangerous journeys, captivity, and warfare, like <em>The Remnant Chronicles</em>.</p>



<p><em>The Hobbit</em> is a classic, with trusty mushroom-loving Bilbo Baggins embarking on a journey that takes him through spider-infested woods, down a river in a barrel, and into the lair of the dragon Smaug.</p>



<p>There are SO MANY adventure fantasies I cannot begin to list them all.</p>



<p><strong>A note before going on:</strong></p>



<p>If theres one thing youll notice on this literary foray, its that some subgenres of fantasy are broad, like massive umbrellas, while others are much tinier and more specific, like cocktail parasols.</p>



<p>Youll also notice (either here or in online bookish communities) that people have different opinions about what defines different subgenres. But dont get lost in the fire swamp with Westley and Buttercup. You dont need to memorize these names (unless you want to).</p>



<p>My ultimate goal is to help you find fantasy books you like. Thats it. Discovering and loving <em>The Moorchild</em> matters a whole lot more than whether its better categorized as a mythic or fairytale fantasy.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading"><span class="ez-toc-section" id="6_Portal_Fantasy"></span>6. Portal Fantasy<span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span></h2>



<p>Quick! Into the Wardrobe, past the thick fur coats, and onto the scrunch of snow. Look, there is a lantern shining in the woods, and here comes a faun to invite you to tea. </p>



<p> Here is a strange bridge to an island covered in drifting leaves, where lies a princess fast asleep. And there is a man who has the power to read characters out of stories, and read people <em>into </em>stories.</p>



<p><strong>In portal fantasies, the characters start in the normal world and then travel through a portal or doorway into a magical world where they must adapt, confront dangers, and deal with magical forces. </strong></p>



<p>Portals merge the allure of low fantasy with high fantasy&#8217;s deep immersion into imaginary worlds. They bridge the magical and the completely ordinary. Perhaps one of us, by reading beautifully, could vanish into the Inkworld. And another could stare into the painting of a ship and be drawn suddenly aboard the Dawn Treader.</p>



<p><strong>Examples of Portal Fantasy</strong></p>



<p>My favorite portal fantasy is <em>Enchantment</em> by Orson Scott Card. Its an adult fantasy about Ivan, a modern-day scholar who crosses a bridge into medieval Russia, where he meets a princess and must help her defeat Baba Yaga. Coming from a cross-cultural background, I love Cards treatment of the cultural tensions and misunderstandings between the two main characters.</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-large is-resized"><picture><source srcset="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Enchantment-1024x683.webp 1024w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Enchantment-300x200.webp 300w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Enchantment-768x512.webp 768w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Enchantment.webp 1200w" sizes="auto, (max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" type="image/webp"><img src="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Enchantment-1024x683.jpg" height="683" width="1024" srcset="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Enchantment-1024x683.jpg 1024w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Enchantment-300x200.jpg 300w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Enchantment-768x512.jpg 768w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Enchantment.jpg 1200w" sizes="auto, (max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" class="wp-image-1264 sp-no-webp" alt="The yellow cover of &quot;Enchantment&quot; appears through a circular lens. It shows a woman sleeping in a massive drift of leaves, surrounded by falling leaves and butterflies. This is a great example of a portal fantasy." loading="lazy" decoding="async" style="width:800px"  > </picture><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">Now that she knew credit cards were valuable, Baba Yaga began to collect as many of them as she could.<br>&nbsp;<strong>Orson Scott Card,&nbsp;</strong><em>Enchantment</em></figcaption></figure>



<p>One of the most well-known portal fantasy series is the <em>Chronicles of Narnia</em> by C.S. Lewis. In the first books, the Pevensie siblings travel through a magic wardrobe into the land of Narnia, where they help defeat the White Witch.</p>



<p>Cornelia Funke&#8217;s <em>Inkheart</em> series is a standby. What better way to enter a book world than through the power of language itself?</p>



<p>Guy Gavriel Kay, another seminal fantasy author, wrote a portal fantasy trilogy called <em>The Fionavar Tapestry</em>. In the books, five university students from Toronto travel to the magical world of Fionavar, where they are caught up in a mythic conflict.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading"><span class="ez-toc-section" id="7_Political_Fantasy"></span>7. Political Fantasy<span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span></h2>



<p><strong>Political fantasy books are about power and intrigue, the subtle machinations of governance, courts, empires, and countries.</strong> Despotic sorcerer kings, court scheming, military campaigns, and rebellious plots abound.</p>



<p>I love the quiet tensions, the incremental shifts in power, the bold coups, and the dialogue brimming with subtext and verbal ripostes. At its best, it shows the complexities of governance, the masks we put on, and the human longings that lie beneath.</p>



<p>Several of my favorite books fall under this umbrella.</p>



<p><strong>Examples of Political Fantasy</strong></p>



<p><a href="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/the-goblin-emperor-review/" data-type="post" data-id="798"><em>The Goblin Emperor </em>is a political fantasy</a> through and through. So is <a href="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/the-thief-book-review/" data-type="post" data-id="747"><em>The Queens Thief </em>series</a> (another favorite), especially <em><a href="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/the-queen-of-attolia-book-review/" data-type="post" data-id="778">The Queen of Attolia</a> (book 2), <a href="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/the-king-of-attolia-review/" data-type="post" data-id="822">The King of Attolia</a> (book 3), </em>and <em>Return of the Thief (book six).&nbsp;</em></p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-large is-resized"><picture><source srcset="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/The-King-of-Attolia-1024x683.webp 1024w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/The-King-of-Attolia-300x200.webp 300w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/The-King-of-Attolia-768x512.webp 768w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/The-King-of-Attolia.webp 1200w" sizes="auto, (max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" type="image/webp"><img src="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/The-King-of-Attolia-1024x683.jpg" height="683" width="1024" srcset="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/The-King-of-Attolia-1024x683.jpg 1024w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/The-King-of-Attolia-300x200.jpg 300w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/The-King-of-Attolia-768x512.jpg 768w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/The-King-of-Attolia.jpg 1200w" sizes="auto, (max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" class="wp-image-1265 sp-no-webp" alt="Jewelry drapes across the cover of a book showing the profile of young man with a scarred face gripping a sword. This is one of my favorite political fantasy books." loading="lazy" decoding="async" style="width:800px"  > </picture><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">One of my all-time favorite political fantasy books</figcaption></figure>



<p><em>Crown Duel, </em>the second book in Sherwood Smiths Crown Duel duet, is another of my political fantasy standbys. Spunky Meliara Astiar is probably the most unsubtle character you can ask for (her go-to behavior is to run at things with sticks and say whatever crosses her mind), so placing her at court leads to some fabulous mishaps.</p>



<p>Other political fantasies Ive enjoyed include Sherwood Smiths <em>Inda Series</em>, and Guy Gavriel Kays <em>The Sarantine Mosaic</em> or standalone <em>Tigana. </em>All are excellent reads<em>.</em></p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading"><span class="ez-toc-section" id="8_Dark_Fantasy"></span>8. Dark Fantasy<span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span></h2>



<p><strong>Darkness, monsters, death, gore, fear, and foreboding are common characteristics of this subgenre.</strong> The characters may be complex with ambiguous morals, tortured heroes, or even villains. I dont mind the move away from stark black and white, tales of good vs evil. I think its important to explore a state closer to reality.</p>



<p>Confession time: this is a subgenre Ive only dipped my toes into. Dark fantasy merges fantasy with horror, and horror is not my go-to vibe. But I have read a few. Its good to mix things up now and then. And some people <em>love </em>dark fantasy. You might too.</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-large is-resized"><picture><source srcset="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Vespertine-Cover-1024x683.webp 1024w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Vespertine-Cover-300x200.webp 300w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Vespertine-Cover-768x512.webp 768w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Vespertine-Cover.webp 1200w" sizes="auto, (max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" type="image/webp"><img src="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Vespertine-Cover-1024x683.jpg" height="683" width="1024" srcset="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Vespertine-Cover-1024x683.jpg 1024w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Vespertine-Cover-300x200.jpg 300w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Vespertine-Cover-768x512.jpg 768w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Vespertine-Cover.jpg 1200w" sizes="auto, (max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" class="wp-image-1266 sp-no-webp" alt="A woman in a dark cloak with startling green eyes glares into the camera, while the left side of the image is obscured by the metallic blur of a knife. This is part of the cover of &quot;Vespertine&quot; by Margaret Rogerson." loading="lazy" decoding="async" style="width:800px"  > </picture><figcaption class="wp-element-caption"><em>Vespertine</em> by Margaret Rogerson is a young adult dark fantasy novel</figcaption></figure>



<p><strong>Examples of Dark Fantasy</strong></p>



<p>So, what dark fantasy books have I read and liked? <em>Gideon the Ninth</em> has a science fiction vibe and is about necromancers and their cavaliers (badass protectors) who have to solve a mystery in a decaying pocket world. The black humor and unique voice of the main character make this a standout book. I enjoyed it and would recommend it, even if the blood, guts, and blobs of fat grossed me out.</p>



<p><em>Vespertine </em>is a young adult dark fantasy about Artemisia, a socially awkward teen with a traumatic past who has to defend her convent against the dead by wielding a relic possessed by a malevolent spirit. The setting is gritty, gray, and populated by corpses, but I enjoyed the character interactions, humorous breaks, and the snarky tone of the malevolent spirit.</p>



<p><em>The Witcher</em> is probably one of the most well-known dark fantasy series out there, with monster hunting, moral ambiguity, violence, corruption, and a grim yet likable antihero. Although I liked the stories, they do have explicit sexual content, which was a detractor for me.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading"><span class="ez-toc-section" id="9_Paranormal_Fantasy"></span>9. Paranormal Fantasy<span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span></h2>



<p>Vampires, werewolves, warlocks, shadowhunters, demons, ghosts, and angels Its paranormal fantasy, popularized by the Twilight series (which, dont shoot me, I havent read.) Paranormal fantasy is a subset of Urban fantasy, so they take place on our world, but are shot through with the supernatural.</p>



<p><strong>Here you might strike up an uneasy alliance with a vampire named Moriarty, learn to draw powerful runes in the fight against demons, speak with ghosts, and traverse energy lines in search of Welsh kings.</strong></p>



<p><strong>Examples of Paranormal Fantasy</strong></p>



<p>Despite not reading Twilight, I <em>have </em>read and liked <em>The Mortal Instruments </em>series by Cassandra Clare. Demon hunters in modern-day New York City, anyone?</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-large is-resized"><picture><source srcset="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/city-of-bones-Cassandra-Clare-1024x683.webp 1024w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/city-of-bones-Cassandra-Clare-300x200.webp 300w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/city-of-bones-Cassandra-Clare-768x512.webp 768w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/city-of-bones-Cassandra-Clare.webp 1200w" sizes="auto, (max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" type="image/webp"><img src="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/city-of-bones-Cassandra-Clare-1024x683.jpg" height="683" width="1024" srcset="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/city-of-bones-Cassandra-Clare-1024x683.jpg 1024w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/city-of-bones-Cassandra-Clare-300x200.jpg 300w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/city-of-bones-Cassandra-Clare-768x512.jpg 768w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/city-of-bones-Cassandra-Clare.jpg 1200w" sizes="auto, (max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" class="wp-image-1267 sp-no-webp" alt="A woman holds a cell phone with a book cover on the screen. It shows a young man with runes pained on his arms surrounded by mythical lights. &quot;City of Bones&quot; by Cassandra Clare is a paranormal fantasy set in New York City." loading="lazy" decoding="async" style="width:800px"  > </picture><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">What do you want?&#8221;<br>&#8220;Just coffee. Black &#8211; like my soul.<br>&nbsp;<strong>Cassandra Clare,&nbsp;</strong><em>City of Bones</em></figcaption></figure>



<p>&nbsp;Another Ive read is <em>The Angel of the Crows,</em> which is Sherlock Holmes-esque with a Paranormal twist, including angels, vampires, and other mythical creatures set in an alternate version of London.</p>



<p>For something a bit lighter and perfectly delightful, I recommend <em>The Graveyard Book</em> by Neil Gaiman. It is loosely based on <em>The Jungle Book</em>, but the little boy is raised by ghosts. Its so well done that it won both the Newbery Medal <em>and</em> the Carnegie Medalthe first time both medals were awarded to the same book.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading"><span class="ez-toc-section" id="10_Romantasy"></span>10. Romantasy<span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span></h2>



<p>All the rage these days, romantasy is a mashup of the romance and fantasy genres. The term is new, but fantasy romance books have been around a long time. So what exactly <em>is</em> romantasy? Well, as with lots of things in the literary world, definitions are subjective.</p>



<p>I appreciated <a href="https://www.writersdigest.com/write-better-fiction/what-is-romantasy-anyway" target="_blank" rel="noopener">M. K. Lobbs thoughts on this subgenre</a>, and her suggestion that<strong> in a romantasy, the romance provides a specific and captivating set of internal stakes and that the plots often follow the traditional romance beats, even if youre not promised that happy ending!</strong> (Beats are shifts in the plot or emotion of a story.)</p>



<p><strong>Examples of Romantasy</strong></p>



<p>While I enjoy romance subplots, romantasy, especially spicy romance, isnt my jam. However, I have read <em>Fourth Wing </em>by Jessica Yaros and the <em>Throne of Glass</em> series by Sarah J. Maas. They are highly popular series worth checking out if you dont mind explicit scenes.</p>



<p>You can find lots of romantasy recommendations in online book communities and forums.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading"><span class="ez-toc-section" id="11_Sword_and_Sorcery"></span>11. Sword and Sorcery<span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span></h2>



<p><strong>Small, personal stakes, sword-wielding rogues with questionable morals, a gritty vibe, and fast-paced action characterize sword and sorcery. </strong></p>



<p>The quests may not always succeed, love is easy but not necessarily lasting, and magic may be a danger to those who wield it.</p>



<p>Although sword and sorcery can take place in invented worlds, it focuses on the personal goals of one or two characters rather than the world-sweeping stakes and huge casts of characters of epic fantasy. The plots are straightforward, the technology is medieval as a rule, and the sorcery is usually nefarious.</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-large is-resized"><picture><source srcset="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Elric-of-Melnibone-audio-1024x683.webp 1024w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Elric-of-Melnibone-audio-300x200.webp 300w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Elric-of-Melnibone-audio-768x512.webp 768w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Elric-of-Melnibone-audio.webp 1200w" sizes="auto, (max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" type="image/webp"><img src="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Elric-of-Melnibone-audio-1024x683.jpg" height="683" width="1024" srcset="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Elric-of-Melnibone-audio-1024x683.jpg 1024w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Elric-of-Melnibone-audio-300x200.jpg 300w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Elric-of-Melnibone-audio-768x512.jpg 768w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Elric-of-Melnibone-audio.jpg 1200w" sizes="auto, (max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" class="wp-image-1269 sp-no-webp" alt="A thin albino figure leans against a tree, wielding a black sword, red eyes fierce. &quot;Elric of Melnibon&quot; by Michael Moorcock is a classic sword and sworcery, one of the subgenres of fantasy." loading="lazy" decoding="async" style="width:800px"  > </picture></figure>



<p><strong>Examples of Sword and Sorcery</strong></p>



<p>Robert E. Howard kicked off this subgenre in the 1930s with his <em>Conan the Barbarian</em> pulp fiction stories (which I havent read yet).</p>



<p>Books Ive read in this subgenre include <em>Elric of Melnibon </em>by Michael Moorcock (one of the influential authors of sword and sorcery) and some of <em>The Witcher </em>books, which are also listed under dark fantasy. Granted, I didn&#8217;t love <em>Elric of Melnibon,</em> but that&#8217;s because the main character made choices that were <em>so dumb</em> I will happily rant about them for ten to twenty minutes.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading"><span class="ez-toc-section" id="12_Cozy_Fantasy"></span>12. Cozy Fantasy<span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span></h2>



<p>Have you noticed that certain subgenres are all about settings, others are about scope, and others are about plot devices or the presence of particular creatures? Other subgenres zoom in on the <em>emotional effect</em>.&nbsp;</p>



<p>So, what do you think of when I say the word cozy? I picture curling up in super soft blankets in front of a fireplace with hot butterbeer, a book, and a plate of Welsh Griddle cakes while fog drifts past the windows. Some Christmas lights wouldn&#8217;t hurt.</p>



<p><strong>Cozy fantasy books embody the cozy vibe. They promise a certain kind of emotion: warmth, comfort, nothing too taxing, and are ultimately relational. </strong>The amount of conflict in a cozy can vary, but these books strive to maintain equilibrium between slice-of-life scenes and conflict.</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-large is-resized"><picture><source srcset="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Book-with-fairy-lights-1024x683.webp 1024w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Book-with-fairy-lights-300x200.webp 300w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Book-with-fairy-lights-768x512.webp 768w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Book-with-fairy-lights.webp 1200w" sizes="auto, (max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" type="image/webp"><img src="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Book-with-fairy-lights-1024x683.jpg" height="683" width="1024" srcset="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Book-with-fairy-lights-1024x683.jpg 1024w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Book-with-fairy-lights-300x200.jpg 300w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Book-with-fairy-lights-768x512.jpg 768w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Book-with-fairy-lights.jpg 1200w" sizes="auto, (max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" class="wp-image-1291 sp-no-webp" alt="A book open on blankets and surrounded by fairy lights. This is an example of cozy fantasy." loading="lazy" decoding="async" style="width:800px"  > </picture></figure>



<p>If you&#8217;re the kind of person who avoids books because you don&#8217;t want to stay up all night reading (a valid fear), cozy fantasy could be perfect for you. In my limited experience, they are easy to pick up, not too hard to put down, and sort of peaceful.</p>



<p><strong>Examples of Cozy Fantasy</strong></p>



<p>Ive barely dipped my toes into cozy fantasy, though I&#8217;m not opposed to reading more. The only book I&#8217;ve read so far that I&#8217;m sure lands in this subgenre has been C.J. Klunes <em>House on the Cerulean</em> <em>Sea</em>.</p>



<p>Although <em>Howl&#8217;s Moving Castle</em> by Diana Wynne Jones includes some elements of danger and conflict, it is a fun adventure tale that is lighthearted enough to qualify as cozy, in my opinion. So does Brandon Sanderson&#8217;s <em>Tress of the Emerald Sea</em>, a whimsical tale of a girl who goes on a sea voyage to rescue her friend from an evil sorceress.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading"><span class="ez-toc-section" id="13_Mythic_Fantasy"></span>13. Mythic Fantasy<span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span></h2>



<p>Here be fairies, creatures you&#8217;ve only heard about around the campfire at night or from the strange old crone with an unusual herb garden and eyes that have seen more than you can ever know.</p>



<p>Magic and myth mingle in mythic fantasy. Here you&#8217;ll encounter worlds populated by Greek and Roman gods, retellings of Norse myths, and series inspired by Slavic fairy tales.</p>



<p><strong>Books in this subgenre draw from the legends, folklore, and deities of cultures around the world, from the Aztecs to the Chinese to the Irish, and everything in between. </strong>Mythic fantasy offers fresh takes on familiar stories, as well as fascinating introductions to different worldviews and belief systems you may not have encountered before.</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-large is-resized"><picture><source srcset="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Moorchild-and-ferns-1024x683.webp 1024w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Moorchild-and-ferns-300x200.webp 300w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Moorchild-and-ferns-768x512.webp 768w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Moorchild-and-ferns.webp 1200w" sizes="auto, (max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" type="image/webp"><img src="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Moorchild-and-ferns-1024x683.jpg" height="683" width="1024" srcset="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Moorchild-and-ferns-1024x683.jpg 1024w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Moorchild-and-ferns-300x200.jpg 300w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Moorchild-and-ferns-768x512.jpg 768w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Moorchild-and-ferns.jpg 1200w" sizes="auto, (max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" class="wp-image-1270 sp-no-webp" alt="An unearthly girl with while pale hair plays a bagpipe chanter. Part of the image is obscured by a spray of bright green fern. This is an example of the mythic fantasy subgenre." loading="lazy" decoding="async" style="width:800px"  > </picture><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">&#8220;Iron made her shiver, made her teeth ache and hurt her if she touched it.&#8221;<br><em>The Moorchild</em> by Eloise McGraw</figcaption></figure>



<p><strong>Examples of Mythic Fantasy</strong></p>



<p>One famous example of mythic fantasy is the <em>Percy Jackson and the Olympians</em> series. They are quite fun.</p>



<p>Books Ive loved in this subgenre include <em>The Moorchild</em> by Eloise McGraw, about a human changeling who doesnt fit among the Folk or among humans and how she finds her way. Another favorite is Katherine Ardens <em>The Winternight Trilogy, </em>which is set in Medieval Russia and draws inspiration from Slavic folklore and deities.</p>



<p>I also enjoyed <em>Uprooted</em> by Naomi Novik. <em>Enchantment</em> by Orson Scott Card probably fits in this genre as well, since Baba Yaga is the villain and there are several nods to Alexander the Great.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading"><span class="ez-toc-section" id="14_Historical_Fantasy"></span>14. Historical Fantasy<span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span></h2>



<p>If you&#8217;ve ever wished you could go back in time and change a historical event, you might love historical fantasy. </p>



<p>As you can guess, <strong>historical fantasy, much like historical fiction, is set during a particular historical period, and can involve real people, places, or events, but aside from that, pretty much anything goes. Magic, dragons, werewolves, battalions of sorcerers.</strong></p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-large is-resized"><picture><source srcset="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Fawkes-1024x768.webp 1024w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Fawkes-300x225.webp 300w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Fawkes-768x576.webp 768w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Fawkes.webp 1200w" sizes="auto, (max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" type="image/webp"><img src="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Fawkes-1024x768.jpg" height="768" width="1024" srcset="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Fawkes-1024x768.jpg 1024w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Fawkes-300x225.jpg 300w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Fawkes-768x576.jpg 768w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Fawkes.jpg 1200w" sizes="auto, (max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" class="wp-image-1272 sp-no-webp" alt="A blue book with a white crackled mask and glints of fire sits on a blue couch. The title reads &quot;Fawkes&quot; by Nadine Brandes, an excellent example of a historical fantasy.
" loading="lazy" decoding="async" style="width:800px"  > </picture><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">Color magic and the Guy Fawke&#8217;s Gunpowder Plot meet in this young adult novel</figcaption></figure>



<p><strong>Examples of Historical Fiction</strong></p>



<p>There are different approaches to historical fantasy, which writer <a href="https://fosteryourwriting.com/2024/06/01/historical-fantasy-a-definition/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">E.S. Foster explains as follows</a>:&nbsp;</p>



<p>1. Those that take place during a specific period in history, like Noviks Temeraire series about the Napoleonic wars with dragons (which I havent read but hear is good).</p>



<p>2. Stories that propose an alternate history, like Nadine Brandes <em>Fawkes.</em> I just read this recently and enjoyed it. Its about the Gunpowder Plot, but the historical event takes place for magical reasons.</p>



<p>3. Lastly, they can include stories that interact with the historical world and a fantasy world, but separately (like C.S. Lewis portal fantasy where the Pevensie children leave WWII England and travel to Narnia).</p>



<p>If you enjoy viking stories with a strong focus on romance, you might <a href="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/sky-in-the-deep-summary-review/">enjoy <em>Sky in the Deep</em> by Adrienne Young</a>.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading"><span class="ez-toc-section" id="15_Fairy_Tale_Fantasy"></span>15. Fairy Tale Fantasy<span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span></h2>



<p>Once upon a time, in a faraway kingdom, there lived a young girl named Cinderella. Unfortunately, her mother had passed away, leaving her alone with her selfish stepmother and stepsisters cue the singing mice, fairy godmother, pumpkins, and glass slippers. </p>



<p><strong>Fairy tale fantasy includes classic fairy tales like Cinderella but also encompasses a whole realm of spinoffs, offshoots, and retellings.</strong> While mythic fantasy tends toward grandeur, <strong>I think of fairy tale fantasy as more grounded and whimsical</strong>, though they don&#8217;t necessarily have to be. Most of Grimm&#8217;s fairy tales are well, grim.</p>



<p>I enjoy the light reads and twists on familiar tales afforded by this subgenre.</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-large is-resized"><picture><source srcset="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Book-of-a-Thousand-Days-Hale-1024x683.webp 1024w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Book-of-a-Thousand-Days-Hale-300x200.webp 300w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Book-of-a-Thousand-Days-Hale-768x512.webp 768w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Book-of-a-Thousand-Days-Hale.webp 1200w" sizes="auto, (max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" type="image/webp"><img src="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Book-of-a-Thousand-Days-Hale-1024x683.jpg" height="683" width="1024" srcset="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Book-of-a-Thousand-Days-Hale-1024x683.jpg 1024w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Book-of-a-Thousand-Days-Hale-300x200.jpg 300w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Book-of-a-Thousand-Days-Hale-768x512.jpg 768w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Book-of-a-Thousand-Days-Hale.jpg 1200w" sizes="auto, (max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" class="wp-image-1274 sp-no-webp" alt="A hand holds a book in front of a branch of wood. The cover shows a black-haired girl with Mongolian features clutches a notebook. This is &quot;Book of a Thousand Days&quot; by Shannon Hale, a fairy-tale fantasy." loading="lazy" decoding="async" style="width:800px"  > </picture></figure>



<p><strong>Examples of Fairy Tale Fantasy</strong></p>



<p>For light fun reads that are very fairy tale-esque, check out Gail Carson Levines fairy-tale rewrites, including <em>Ella Enchanted </em>and <em>Fairest</em>. Ive also really enjoyed Shannon Hales books, including <em>The Goose Girl </em>and <em>Enna Burning</em>.</p>



<p>My favorite of Hales novels is <em>Book of a Thousand Days,</em> which is loosely based on Grimms Fairy Tale about Maid Maleen, but is set in a secondary world inspired by Mongolia. How cool is that? Ive read it many times, and it never gets old.</p>



<p>Naomi Noviks <em>Spinning Silver</em> is another fairy-tale fantasy worth checking out.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading"><span class="ez-toc-section" id="16_Nautical_Fantasy"></span>16. Nautical Fantasy<span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span></h2>



<p><strong>Salty breezes, sinewy sea beasts, enchanted islands, pirates, and scrambling in the riggingfind it in nautical fantasy.</strong> If youve ever dreamed of sailing the high seas, felt the allure of the ocean, or wanted to dive for treasure, youll love this subgenre.</p>



<p>I love nautical fantasy and need to find more books that take place at sea. The ocean is a world of its own, after all, full of dangers and the potential for high stakes conflict. Perhaps it has some cross-over with political fiction, too, since a ship at sea is a kingdom unto itself.</p>



<p><strong>Examples of Nautical Fantasy</strong></p>



<p>Here are a few of my favorites: <em>The Liveship Traders </em>series is a fantastic adult epic fantasy series about sentient ships, pirates, magic, and mystical islands.</p>



<p>Although the first book in Sherwood Smiths <em>Inda</em> series takes place on land, the remaining three take place on the high seas, complete with politics, sea battles, and epic strategy. I highly recommend them! I found them so engrossing that it was hard to sleep so maybe read them when youre on vacation.</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-large is-resized"><picture><source srcset="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Liveship-Traders-Hobb-1024x683.webp 1024w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Liveship-Traders-Hobb-300x200.webp 300w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Liveship-Traders-Hobb-768x512.webp 768w,https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Liveship-Traders-Hobb.webp 1200w" sizes="auto, (max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" type="image/webp"><img src="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Liveship-Traders-Hobb-1024x683.jpg" height="683" width="1024" srcset="https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Liveship-Traders-Hobb-1024x683.jpg 1024w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Liveship-Traders-Hobb-300x200.jpg 300w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Liveship-Traders-Hobb-768x512.jpg 768w, https://yvonnemcarthur.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Liveship-Traders-Hobb.jpg 1200w" sizes="auto, (max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" class="wp-image-1275 sp-no-webp" alt="Three books in a row showing mythical ships. This is The Liveship Traders trilogy, excellent adult fantasy books about sentient ships and their human crew." loading="lazy" decoding="async" style="width:800px"  > </picture></figure>



<p>For a less epic and more personal story, Brandon Sandersons standalone novel <em>Tress of the Emerald Sea</em> is a fun easy read.</p>



<p><em>Fable</em> by Adrienne Young is also set mostly at sea. Its been quite a while since I read it, but I remember liking the unique setting, especially the more Caribbean vibe. Parts of the plot didnt land for me, but its worth checking out if you enjoy young adult books.&nbsp;</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading"><span class="ez-toc-section" id="17_Academy_FantasyDark_Academia"></span>17. Academy Fantasy/Dark Academia<span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span></h2>



<p>As you can guess by the name, academy fantasies take place in schools or academies. </p>



<p>These are the books where we take potions class with Severus Snape (though I&#8217;d much rather Charms with Professor Flitwick or Herbology with Professor Sprout), complain about foot-long essays, convince strange school libraries to give us their most valuable tomes, and are turned into geese by our teachers.</p>



<p>We&#8217;ve all been students, harped about homework, had teachers we didn&#8217;t get on with (and others we did), and had to muddle through exams. <strong>Academy fantasy takes the familiar world of academics and transports it, making it more awful or more fun, or at least more fantastical.</strong> </p>



<p>For people still in the throes of studenthood, there is a resonance among the pages. For the rest of us, there&#8217;s recognition, the spark of old memories, maybe a modicum of nostalgia.</p>



<p><strong>Examples of Academy Fantasy </strong></p>



<p> I would be remiss if I didnt mention the <em>Harry Potter</em> series here, which is the most famous example. (I reread these shortly before writing this, and ah, theyre so good!)</p>



<p>Another book I love in this subgenre is <em>A Stranger to Command</em> by Sherwood Smith. Its the military academy prequel to <em>Crown Duel</em> with nods to the <em>Inda</em> series, cross-cultural tensions, and great characterization.</p>
